docs.title: Documentation Strategy & Metrics
docs.text:
This page outlines my approach to building, scaling, and measuring enterprise SaaS documentation using a Docs-as-Code model.

The goal of documentation is not just completeness—but clarity, adoption, and measurable business impact.

docs.title: Documentation philosophy
docs.text: My documentation strategy is guided by four core principles.

docs.title: Docs are a product
docs.text: Documentation is treated as a first-class product with: - Clear ownership - Defined audiences - Roadmaps aligned to product releases - Quality and success metrics

docs.title: Audience-first information architecture
docs.text:
Content is intentionally layered to support different audiences:

  • Executives: What’s New, Release Highlights
  • End users: User Guides, How-To Guides
  • Support teams: FAQs, Troubleshooting
  • Product teams: Release Notes, UX Copy

Each layer answers a different question without duplicating content.

docs.title: Docs-as-Code for scale and quality
docs.text:
All documentation is managed using: - Git-based workflows - Markdown source files - Structured navigation - Version-controlled reviews

This approach enables faster updates, consistent formatting, peer reviews, and traceability across releases.

docs.title: Documentation supports adoption and deflection
docs.text: Documentation success is measured by how well it: - Enables users to complete tasks independently - Reduces support dependency - Improves feature adoption - Builds trust in the product

docs.title: Release-driven documentation
docs.text: Documentation planning is aligned with the product release cycle: - Release Notes and What’s New drafted in parallel with development - User Guides and How-To content updated for major workflows - UX copy reviewed before feature launch

docs.title: Ownership and quality standards
docs.text:
• Each product area has a designated documentation owner
  • Writers partner with Product, Engineering, UX, and Support
  • Standards ensure terminology consistency, task completeness, accessibility, and clear UX microcopy

docs.title: Documentation lifecycle efficiency
docs.text:
Feature Design → UX Copy → Draft → Review → Publish → Measure → Improve

Documentation is created early, reviewed thoroughly, and continuously improved using real usage data.

How documentation flows through a release 1. Feature design: scope, users, and risks identified early 2. UX copy alignment: terminology finalized with design 3. Draft documentation: workflows documented in parallel 4. Review and validation: peer and SME feedback 5. Publish with release: docs ship with product 6. Measure and improve: analytics and support insights drive updates

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: This section answers common questions related to forecasting, budgeting, and AI-assisted insights.

docs.title: Can I create multiple forecasts for the same period?
docs.text: Yes. You can create multiple forecast versions to model different scenarios and assumptions.

docs.title: Can forecasts be locked?
docs.text: Yes. Forecasts can be locked after submission to prevent further changes.

docs.title: Does AI change my data automatically?
docs.text: No. AI insights are advisory only. They highlight patterns and anomalies but do not modify values.

docs.title: How accurate are AI recommendations?
docs.text: AI insights are based on historical data patterns and should be reviewed alongside business context.

docs.title: Can multiple users work on the same forecast?
docs.text: Yes. Forecasting supports collaboration with role-based access and approval workflows.

docs.title: Is there an audit trail?
docs.text: Yes. All changes are tracked with user, timestamp, and value history.

docs.title: How does the platform handle large datasets?
docs.text: The platform is optimized for enterprise-scale data volumes and supports efficient recalculation and aggregation.

docs.title: How to Create a Budget
docs.text: This guide walks you through creating a budget using forecast data and assumptions.

docs.title: Before you begin
docs.text: Ensure that: - You have access to the planning workspace - Required dimensions (time, department, account) are available - A baseline forecast or actuals exist

docs.title: Step 1: Create a new budget version
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Planning > Budgets
  2. Select Create New Version
  3. Enter a name and description
  4. Choose the time period for the budget

docs.title: Step 2: Select a starting point
docs.text:
You can initialize a budget using: - Prior year actuals - Latest forecast version - A blank template

Select the option that best aligns with your planning approach.

docs.title: Step 3: Apply assumptions
docs.text:
Apply budget assumptions such as: - Percentage growth or reduction - Headcount changes - Seasonal adjustments

Assumptions can be applied globally or at a granular level.

docs.title: Step 4: Review AI insights (optional)
docs.text:
If enabled, AI insights may: - Flag values that deviate significantly from historical trends - Highlight areas requiring closer review

Use these insights to validate assumptions.

docs.title: Step 5: Submit for approval
docs.text: Once complete: 1. Review totals and summaries 2. Submit the budget for approval 3. Track approval status within the workflow

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text: After approval, budgets can be: - Locked for reporting - Compared against actuals - Used as inputs for future forecasts

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: This section helps you resolve common issues related to forecasting and budgeting.

docs.title: Forecast values are not updating
docs.text:
Possible causes: - The forecast version is locked - Required drivers are missing - You do not have edit permissions

Resolution: - Verify version status - Check driver configuration - Confirm your access level

docs.title: AI insights are not visible
docs.text:
Possible causes: - AI features are disabled for your role - Insufficient historical data - Data refresh is incomplete

Resolution: - Contact an administrator - Ensure sufficient historical data exists - Retry after data refresh

docs.title: Approval workflow is blocked
docs.text:
Possible causes: - Pending approvals - Missing required reviewers

Resolution: - Review workflow status - Ensure all required approvers are assigned

docs.title: Performance issues when opening large forecasts
docs.text:
Possible causes: - Large dimensionality - Concurrent user activity

Resolution: - Filter data where possible - Work with administrators to optimize models

docs.title: Build a Forecast Scenario
docs.text:
This guide explains how to create forecast scenarios to evaluate different business outcomes under varying assumptions.

Forecast scenarios help teams model uncertainty and support data-driven decision-making.

docs.title: Step 1: Create a new forecast version
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Planning > Forecasts
  2. Select Create New Version
  3. Choose Scenario Forecast
  4. Enter a name and description

Use clear naming to distinguish scenarios (for example, Best Case or Conservative).

docs.title: Step 2: Select a baseline
docs.text:
Choose a starting point: - Latest approved forecast - Approved budget - Actuals-to-date

Baselines ensure consistency across scenarios.

docs.title: Step 3: Apply scenario-specific assumptions
docs.text:
Adjust assumptions such as: - Revenue growth rates - Headcount changes - Cost increase or reduction

Assumptions can be applied globally or at a granular level.

docs.title: Step 4: Review AI-assisted insights
docs.text:
AI insights may: - Highlight unusual variances - Surface potential forecast risks - Identify areas that require closer review

Insights are advisory and should be reviewed alongside business context.

docs.title: Step 5: Save and validate
docs.text: Save the scenario and review validation messages. Resolve any issues before proceeding.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
After creating scenarios, review results and submit the selected forecast for approval.

docs.title: Forecasting Overview
docs.text:
This guide provides an overview of the forecasting capabilities available in the platform and explains how finance teams can create, manage, and refine forecasts at scale.

Forecasting is designed for enterprise planning scenarios where accuracy, auditability, and collaboration are critical.

docs.title: What you can do with Forecasting
docs.text:
Using Forecasting, you can:

  • Create rolling and static forecasts across time horizons
  • Model multiple forecast scenarios for comparison
  • Incorporate historical actuals and assumptions
  • Collaborate across finance and business teams
  • Leverage AI-assisted insights to identify trends and anomalies

docs.title: Forecast versions
docs.text: Forecasts are created as versions, allowing you to: - Maintain a baseline forecast - Create alternative scenarios (Best Case, Worst Case) - Lock versions for audit and reporting purposes

docs.title: Driver-based forecasting
docs.text:
Driver-based models allow forecast values to be calculated using: - Growth rates - Headcount drivers - Volume-based assumptions

This approach improves consistency and reduces manual effort.

docs.title: AI-assisted forecasting insights
docs.text:
AI-assisted forecasting analyzes historical data and forecast inputs to: - Highlight unusual variances - Surface potential risks early - Suggest adjustment areas based on past patterns

These insights are advisory and do not modify forecast values automatically.

docs.title: Governance and controls
docs.text: Forecasting includes enterprise-grade controls such as: - Role-based access - Approval workflows - Change history tracking - Forecast locking after submission

docs.title: When to use Forecasting
docs.text:
Forecasting is typically used: - During monthly or quarterly planning cycles - For scenario modeling and sensitivity analysis - To support executive reporting and decision-making

Next: Build a Forecast Scenario ➡

docs.title: Review and Submit a Forecast
docs.text: This guide explains how to review forecast results and submit a forecast for approval.

docs.title: Step 1: Review forecast summaries
docs.text:
Review key metrics such as: - Total revenue - Expense trends - Variance from prior versions

Use summary views to identify areas requiring attention.

docs.title: Step 2: Evaluate AI insights and warnings
docs.text:
AI insights and warnings may highlight: - Large variances - Confidence indicators - Potential forecast risks

Address these items before submission.

docs.title: Step 3: Add review comments
docs.text:
Add contextual comments to: - Explain assumptions - Capture decision rationale - Highlight risks or dependencies

Comments improve collaboration and audit readiness.

docs.title: Step 4: Submit for approval
docs.text:
1. Select Submit for Approval
  2. Review submission details
  3. Confirm approval workflow participants

After submission, editing may be restricted.

docs.title: Step 5: Track approval status
docs.text: Track approval progress directly within the forecast. Notifications alert you when action is required.

docs.title: What happens next
docs.text:
Once approved, the forecast can be: - Locked for reporting - Used in executive dashboards - Compared against actuals

docs.title: What’s New in 2026.1
docs.text: The 2026.1 release focuses on improving forecast confidence, decision-making speed, and governance across planning cycles.

docs.title: Smarter forecasting with AI-assisted insights
docs.text:
Finance teams now get clearer visibility into forecast risks and unexpected trends.

AI-assisted insights highlight: - Unusual variances compared to historical patterns - Potential risk areas before submission - Confidence indicators to guide review

Why it matters: Teams can identify issues earlier and reduce last-minute surprises.

docs.title: Faster performance for large planning models
docs.text:
Forecast recalculation and data refresh times have been significantly improved for enterprise-scale models.

Why it matters: Large organizations can iterate faster without waiting on system updates.

docs.title: Improved forecast submission and approvals
docs.text:
Approval workflows are now clearer and more transparent, with better visibility into approval status and ownership.

Why it matters: Teams spend less time tracking approvals and more time analyzing results.

docs.title: Clearer user guidance and validation messages
docs.text:
Updated in-product messages help users understand required actions and next steps during forecasting and budgeting.

Why it matters: Reduced errors and smoother planning workflows.
